alert.note: Alert for Lincoln; Teton (Wyoming) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued April 27 at 5:50PM MDT by NWS Riverton
info.description: ...Warming Temperatures this Weekend Increase Snow Melt and the Potential for Flooding... Temperatures steadily climb Saturday through Monday, which will melt low elevation and foothill snow across far west Wyoming. High temperatures in the valleys will range from 55 to 65 each afternoon with a few readings nearing 70 by Monday. These warm temperatures could result in significant melting of low elevation snow given the deep snowpack that still exists in the valleys. As of Thursday, April 27, many locations still had a snow depth of 12 to 24 inches. Bedford and Star Valley Ranch reported the greatest snow depth of 31 and 28 inches, respectively. Rapid melting of this snowpack could quickly raise the water levels in smaller tributary creeks and streams in the Bear, Salt, and Snake River basins of Lincoln and Teton counties. Now would be the time to clear snow, ice, and debris from culverts and other flow paths to allow runoff to flow away from buildings and other vulnerable infrastructure. This could include moving deep snow away from the foundations of buildings, relocating equipment to higher ground, and moving livestock out of poorly drained or low-lying areas. Stay tuned for the latest river forecasts. Remember, if you encounter a flooded roadway, turn around don`t drown. You never know what road conditions are hidden under the water.
